content: General description of the spatial database MOFgeoDB
description: General description of the spatial database MOFgeoDB
excerpt_html: General description of the spatial database MOFgeoDB
excerpt_text: General description of the spatial database MOFgeoDB
html: General description of the spatial database MOFgeoDB
summary:
General Setting The MOFgeoDB is a SQlite database using the spatial extension spatialite and serves our data of vegetation (mainly trees) and study plots for ecosystem research (forest structure, experiments) over time. Additional there are some auxiliary datasets (geopackage) of infrastructure for visual reasons. QGIS is used as back-end for analysis and visualization. All data is available at GitHub Repo MOFgeoDB.
 Relational Structure First overview of the relational structure gives figure 1.
title: Description MOFgeoDB

content: Various plot designs in the MOF
description: Various plot designs in the MOF
excerpt_html: Various plot designs in the MOF
excerpt_text: Various plot designs in the MOF
html: Various plot designs in the MOF
summary:
Survey Plots Forest Structure – fs Plots for surveying forest structure are setup by various student groups since 2017. The decision where to set up a plot follows no random or systematic scheme (what a pitty!) but is somehow accidental.
General characteristics are: * circular 10m radius in horizontal plane * slope * aspect * remarks on special items
All plots are marked with a central point (stored in topopoint (see figure 1).
title: Plots

content: Views are used to get a defined subset and collection of data from different relations.
description: Views are used to get a defined subset and collection of data from different relations.
excerpt_html: Views are used to get a defined subset and collection of data from different relations.
excerpt_text: Views are used to get a defined subset and collection of data from different relations.
html: Views are used to get a defined subset and collection of data from different relations.
summary:
Views Views are used to get a defined subset and collection of data from different relations. All views are nemed with a prefix vw_.
Time dependent data For all time dependent data views on the actual dataset is implement to get a single 1:1 connection. For example the view on the lut_tree_state table:
CREATE VIEW vw_actual_tree_state AS SELECT id,tree_id,creator_id, max(date) AS date, state_id, remarks FROM tree_state GROUP BY tree_id; Following views are implemented:
title: Views

content: All custom made triggers in the MOFgeoDB
description: All custom made triggers in the MOFgeoDB
excerpt_html: All custom made triggers in the MOFgeoDB
excerpt_text: All custom made triggers in the MOFgeoDB
html: All custom made triggers in the MOFgeoDB
summary:
All custom made triggers in the MOFgeoDB Triggers run automatically before or after a specific command is executed on the database. They are absolutely necessary to keep the database running. There are many more triggers which are created automatically by spatialite to keep the geometries consistent. Please remember:
 A TRIGGER that has not been properly tested is called a … ¡¡¡ D I S A S T E R !
title: Triggers

automatic statistical analysis in the database analysis in the context of individual research questions  Statistics of plots forest structure  PlotBook  Selection of fs-plot Are the plots randomly chosen and represent the mean of their surrounding?

title: Analysis

summary:
General Situation Collecting data happens in various ways:
systematic in context of research more or less chaotic in the context of teaching private to fill the gaps of 2. or any other reason automatic in a fixed time interval individual once in a lifetime or in a fixed interval  The second pretends not collecting faulty data but during courses often time is limited to collect everything is needed or the intention of the course is just focused on a special question or learning the actual method.
title: Data Collecting
